messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] yoshiro school tsuba?
messages.msgSnippet: Ron, Alan and all, another one that draws both sides to comment. I think this is late Muromachi/very early Edo Heianjô Zogan. Others on this list agree whilst
messages.messageBody:
Ron, Alan and all, another one that draws both sides to comment. I think
this is late Muromachi/very early Edo Heianjô Zogan. Others on this list
agree whilst still others on this list think Kaga Yoshiro. I can see
bit's of both in each, this is about 2mm thick and about 8.5 x 8 cm, it
is heavy and looks to be sand iron, I think

http://www.nihontomessageboard.com/tsuba_collection/heianjo-zogan.jpg

I agree on the article, I too think it would be an excellent read.

Rich

Ron Hartmann wrote:

> This discussion would make such an interesting article if put
> together, for the JSS/US Newsletter. I can envision perhaps a dozen
> examples of zogan tsuba, representative of where it began to be used
> through to the more common Kyo-zogan work of mid-Edo. It seems Jim,
> Alan Harvie and Bob Haynes did this at one of the SF shows two or
> three years ago. Perhaps such a "comparison" or "evolution of the
> technique" has already been put together? If so, it would be a
> wonderful article to see in print for sharing. Comments?
>
> Ron
> STL




[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] yoshiro school tsuba?
messages.msgSnippet: Sounds great Ron.  That is the kind of stuff we need in the JSSUS newsletter.  Looking forward to it! Mike
messages.messageBody:
Sounds great Ron. That is the kind of stuff we need in the JSSUS
newsletter. Looking forward to it!
Mike

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] yoshiro school tsuba?
messages.msgSnippet: This discussion would make such an interesting article if put together, for the JSS/US Newsletter. I can envision perhaps a dozen examples of zogan tsuba,
messages.messageBody:
This discussion would make such an interesting article if put together, for the JSS/US Newsletter. I can envision perhaps a dozen examples of zogan tsuba, representative of where it began to be used through to the more common Kyo-zogan work of mid-Edo. It seems Jim, Alan Harvie and Bob Haynes did this at one of the SF shows two or three years ago. Perhaps such a "comparison" or "evolution of the technique" has already been put together? If so, it would be a wonderful article to see in print for sharing. Comments?

Ron
STL
----- Original Message -----
From: Alan Bale
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Sunday, April 24, 2005 1:58 PM
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] yoshiro school tsuba?


Ron, Barry,
When I said Kaga I meant Kaga-zogan and early, I don't think it is Kaga
Yoshiro, I don't have the image now so I can't check my first impression.

Alan

----- Original Message -----
From: "Ron Hartmann" <swords@...>
To: <nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com>
Sent: Saturday, April 23, 2005 9:15 PM
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] yoshiro school tsuba?


>
> Hi Alan -
>
> Sorry. When I said Kaga and the Yoshiro, I meant Kaga Yoshiro and the
Yoshiro of Kyoto area. (I think that's right, right?)
>
> When thinking Kaga Yoshiro, I've had the impression that more often they
would have squarish-type hitsuana; these are conventional shape with the
kogai histsu being very "rounded/drilled-like" as you see on many of the
Kyo-sukashi tsuba. That was my thinking here. Not sure why, but I also
thought Kaga Yoshiro tsuba were more of a thinner plate than the others, but
I'm not sure where that idea came from.
>
> Ron
> STL

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] yoshiro school tsuba?
messages.msgSnippet: Well, the karakusa leaf does remind me of Kaga-Fushimi work.  My sample of ONE was a 2 inch kojiri on a katana I once had.  I saw similar work in one of Bob
messages.messageBody:
Well, the karakusa leaf does remind me of Kaga-Fushimi work. My sample of ONE
was a 2 inch kojiri on a katana I once had. I saw similar work in one of Bob
Haynes' catalogues that he called Kaga Fushimi. That's the beginning and end of
my knowledge on this, except that I do have a Heianjo/Yoshiro zogan tsuba the
same as the one in Gary D. Murtha's Vol 1 (? - maybe Vol 2). Oh, in Kaga
Fushimi work the leaves were modelled in a copper-like alloy and the veins
incised, so the resemblance in this case is only superficial. I'm not making an
authoritative statement here...
Barry Thomas.

----- Original Message -----
From: Ron Hartmann <swords@...>
To: <nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com>
Sent: Sunday, April 24, 2005 6:15 AM
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] yoshiro school tsuba?



Hi Alan -

Sorry. When I said Kaga and the Yoshiro, I meant Kaga Yoshiro and the Yoshiro of
Kyoto area. (I think that's right, right?)

When thinking Kaga Yoshiro, I've had the impression that more often they would
have squarish-type hitsuana; these are conventional shape with the kogai histsu
being very "rounded/drilled-like" as you see on many of the Kyo-sukashi tsuba.
That was my thinking here. Not sure why, but I also thought Kaga Yoshiro tsuba
were more of a thinner plate than the others, but I'm not sure where that idea
came from.

Ron
STL

----- Original Message -----
From: Alan Bale
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Saturday, April 23, 2005 3:04 PM
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] yoshiro school tsuba?

It looks like Kaga to me, don't forget that you also divide Yoshiro into
'Kaga Yoshiro' and 'Bizen Yoshiro'.

Alan

----- Original Message -----
From: "dirk marshall" <dirkmarshall@...>

Subject: [nihontostudy] yoshiro school tsuba?

was wondering if this could be a yoshino or kaga tsuba. As you can see I
don't know much other than what I like. The inlay goes around and on the
edge.

http://www.freeimagelibrary.com/images/dirkmarshall/leaf.jpg<http://www.freeimag

> Dirk

messages.msgSnippet: Hi Alan - Sorry. When I said Kaga and the Yoshiro, I meant Kaga Yoshiro and the Yoshiro of Kyoto area. (I think that s right, right?) When thinking Kaga
messages.messageBody:
Hi Alan -

Sorry. When I said Kaga and the Yoshiro, I meant Kaga Yoshiro and the Yoshiro of Kyoto area. (I think that's right, right?)

When thinking Kaga Yoshiro, I've had the impression that more often they would have squarish-type hitsuana; these are conventional shape with the kogai histsu being very "rounded/drilled-like" as you see on many of the Kyo-sukashi tsuba. That was my thinking here. Not sure why, but I also thought Kaga Yoshiro tsuba were more of a thinner plate than the others, but I'm not sure where that idea came from.

Ron
STL

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] yoshiro school tsuba?
messages.msgSnippet: hi, Thanks, I bought this with the other so I was kind of thinking that maybe the guy bought them together or liked them as the other was. Dirk ... From: Ron
messages.messageBody:
hi,
Thanks, I bought this with the other so I was kind of thinking that maybe the guy bought them together or liked them as the other was.

Dirk
----- Original Message -----
From: Ron Hartmann<mailto:swords@...>
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com<mailto:nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com>
Sent: 04/23/2005 2:11 PM
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] yoshiro school tsuba?


Nice tsuba, Dirk. I would not call this Kaga work, more likely Yoshiro or simply Heianjo zogan (if not Yoshiro). The kogai hitsuana looks very Kyoto to me. I also think Yoshiro work was "outlined" with chisel marks...not sure about that. (Maybe that was a way to distinguish between Yoshiro and Onin? Suspect Onin work was done that way.) Sorry to be sound so confusing here. Nice overlapping zogan...my guess is Yoshiro.

Ron
STL
----- Original Message -----
From: dirk marshall
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Saturday, April 23, 2005 1:56 PM
Subject: [nihontostudy] yoshiro school tsuba?


I bought this with the other and got a good deal as they were rusty. I was wondering if this could be a yoshino or kaga tsuba. As you can see I don't know much other than what I like. The inlay goes around and on the edge.

http://www.freeimagelibrary.com/images/dirkmarshall/leaf.jpg<http://www.freeimagelibrary.com/images/dirkmarshall/leaf.jpg><http://www.freeimagelibrary.com/images/dirkmarshall/leaf.jpg<http://www.freeimagelibrary.com/images/dirkmarshall/leaf.jpg>>

Thanks
Dirk

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] yoshiro school tsuba?
messages.msgSnippet: Nice tsuba, Dirk. I would not call this Kaga work, more likely Yoshiro or simply Heianjo zogan (if not Yoshiro). The kogai hitsuana looks very Kyoto to me. I
messages.messageBody:
Nice tsuba, Dirk. I would not call this Kaga work, more likely Yoshiro or simply Heianjo zogan (if not Yoshiro). The kogai hitsuana looks very Kyoto to me. I also think Yoshiro work was "outlined" with chisel marks...not sure about that. (Maybe that was a way to distinguish between Yoshiro and Onin? Suspect Onin work was done that way.) Sorry to be sound so confusing here. Nice overlapping zogan...my guess is Yoshiro.

Ron
STL
----- Original Message -----
From: dirk marshall
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Saturday, April 23, 2005 1:56 PM
Subject: [nihontostudy] yoshiro school tsuba?


I bought this with the other and got a good deal as they were rusty. I was wondering if this could be a yoshino or kaga tsuba. As you can see I don't know much other than what I like. The inlay goes around and on the edge.

http://www.freeimagelibrary.com/images/dirkmarshall/leaf.jpg<http://www.freeimagelibrary.com/images/dirkmarshall/leaf.jpg>

Thanks
Dirk
